author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Robert Downey Jr. and wife Susan have strict rule they follow in their marriage
text: Robert Downey Jr.'s wife has revealed the secret to their 18-year-marriage. The film producer has revealed she and the Oppenheimer star have a rule to ensure they spend enough time together amid their busy schedules. The Sherlock Holmes producer then acknowledged that their jobs can often be "unpredictable" Summary by Ground News 3 Articles 3 Articles All Left Center Right [] Film News Robert Downey Jr.'s wife Susan reveals the secret to their 18-year-marriage Robert Downey Jr.'s wife Susan reveals the secret to their 18-year-marriage - The Number One magazine feat. news, reviews, movie trailers, cinema, DVDs, interviews + film & movie gossip UK & worldwide. 6 hours ago·United KingdomRead Full Article [] celebtattler.com Robert Downey Jr.'s Wife Reveals Secret to 18-Year Marriage: The '2-Week Rule' In a recent interview with PEOPLE, Susan Downey, wife of renowned actor Robert Downey Jr., unveils a key element that has kept their 18-year marriage steadfast: the "two-week rule." This rule ensures that the family never stays apart for more than a fortnight at a stretch. "We do have a two-week rule, which often feels too long, but we don't go more than two weeks without seeing each other and the family being together," Susan shared in the late… 4 hours agoRead Full Article Think freely.Subscribe and get full access to Ground NewsSubscriptions start at $9.99/year [Subscribe](/subscribe) Not enough coverage to generate an Article Assistant. author: Gabriela Bernal
title: Opinion | North Korean intervention in Ukraine is the last thing the world needs | South China Morning Post
text:
Last week, South Korea and Ukraine accused North Korea of deploying troops to support Russia in its war in Ukraine. North Korea denies doing so. This week, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin said there was “evidence” of North Korean troops in Russia, but that what they are doing there “is left to be seen”.
Pyongyang sending troops to fight in Ukraine would signal North Korea’s evolution from an isolated pariah state to a tangible threat to international security – one that can directly influence conflicts thousands of miles away from the Korean peninsula and potentially reshape global security.
The evidence of North Korea’s military intervention is mounting. Last week, South Korea’s National Intelligence Service said Russian naval vessels were transporting North Korean special forces units and that the troops were being stationed in Russia’s Far East. It also said North Korean military officers had visited a missile launch site near the Russia-Ukraine war front in August.
Ukraine released a video which appears to show North Korean soldiers receiving uniforms in Russia. While the video could not be independently verified, Korean speech is audible in the background.
These developments seem to corroborate Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky’s earlier statement that over 10,000 North Korean troops were preparing to join Russian forces and previous Ukrainian media reports stating that six North Korean officers had been killed in a Ukrainian missile attack near Donetsk on October 3.
If, as South Korea’s intelligence service says, around 1,500 North Korean soldiers are already in Vladivostok, it is clear that the mutual defence pact signed by Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in June was much more than bravado. While there have been reports of shipments of North Korean weapons for Russian use in Ukraine for more than a year, sending soldiers to fight on the ground would cross a critical red line.


Zelensky has warned that a third nation joining the hostilities could turn the conflict into a “world war”. According to the head of Ukrainian military intelligence, the 10,000 North Korean troops will be ready to fight in Ukraine on November 1.
While some analysts suggest these troops are likely to end up serving as cannon fodder for Russia’s war effort, the implications extend far beyond Ukraine’s battlefields. For one, North Korea would gain invaluable combat experience, crucial for any potential conflict with South Korea, in which ground forces would likely play a decisive role.
Moreover, in exchange for this military support, Moscow could help Pyongyang acquire fighter aircraft, surface-to-air missiles, armoured vehicles and nuclear technology expertise.


Beyond Europe, the implications of Pyongyang’s choices will also negatively affect stability on the Korean peninsula and in East Asia more broadly. North Korean media reported last week that the country had blown up roads and railways connecting the two Koreas in accordance with a constitutional stipulation that South Korea is a “hostile state”.
This signals that North Korea’s constitution may indeed have been amended to reflect the change in the country’s unification policy announced last December.
Tensions could get worse in the coming weeks, however, with North Korea warning of retaliation in response to a South Korean drone allegedly infiltrating its capital’s airspace.
Moreover, North Korea’s strengthening military relationship with Russia provides it with a powerful alternative to Chinese support, potentially emboldening Pyongyang to take more aggressive action against South Korea. Heightened tensions between the two Koreas would further destabilise the region, with increasing US-Japan-South Korea military cooperation unlikely to go unnoticed by Beijing.

Clearly, years of sanctions and deterrence efforts by the US and its allies have done little to curb North Korea’s military growth. Nevertheless, South Korea, the US and Japan announced the launch of a new sanctions monitoring mechanism with eight other countries last week. If history is any indication, however, the efforts are likely to be in vain, particularly given China and Russia’s strong opposition to UN sanctions targeting Pyongyang.
Moreover, the approaching US presidential election creates a potential window of opportunity for Russia and North Korea to advance their objectives while Washington’s attention is focused domestically. Moscow could significantly ramp up its offensive against Ukraine with North Korean help, further shifting the war’s outcome in its favour. The risk of the war expanding beyond Ukraine into other European territories can also not be ignored.
One key question in Europe will be whether South Korea will agree to send lethal aid to Ukraine. Seoul’s presidential office convened an emergency security meeting on Friday after the revelations by the country’s intelligence service, stating that the government “plans to actively pursue necessary measures” in response. A change in South Korea’s stance could have a major impact in Ukraine’s favour, given the Asian nation’s vast stockpiles of artillery and wide range of highly desirable military equipment.
Providing lethal aid to Ukraine would be a double-edged sword for Seoul, however, as it would be likely to elicit a powerful response from North Korea. Even if South Korean lethal aid helps Kyiv balance against the presence of North Korean troops, Pyongyang may choose to dispatch more military personnel, provide Russia with more destructive weapons, or conduct more dangerous military provocations along the inter-Korean border.
A strong and coordinated international response is needed. The era of “strategic patience” must end. If the next US president does not overhaul decades of failed North Korea policy and find a way to resume diplomatic dialogue with Pyongyang, there may be worse to come from North Korea. As long as diplomacy between Washington and Pyongyang remains nonexistent, North Korea will continue expanding its military endeavours across international borders.

author: Sarah Cartlidge
title: Met Office issues wind warning for Bournemouth and Dorset | Bournemouth Echo
text:
A NEW warning for strong winds has been issued for Dorset with gusts set to reach up to 75mph.
The Met Office has issued warnings for Bournemouth , Christchurch, Poole, and the rest of the county.
The warning will be in force from 11am on Saturday, December 30, until 3am on Sunday, December 31.
A Met Office spokesperson said: “An active cold front will move east across England and Wales during Saturday and into Sunday and will be characterised by strong winds and some heavy rain.
“Gusts of 45-50 mph widely, but squally near the cold front with some gusts around 60 mph, whilst the strongest gusts are likely near coasts in the west and south, with 65-75 mph in places.”
The Met Office says some delays to road, rail, air and ferry transport are “likely”.
Large waves and spray could affect some coastal routes, seafronts and coastal communities.
Power cuts could also occur, the Met Office said.
The new weather warning comes after Storm Gerrit brought strong winds to Dorset .
According to the Met Office forecast, Saturday will be mostly dry during the day, with heavy rain expected between 7pm and midnight.
Sunday will see light showers giving way to sunshine in the afternoon.
Weather Dorset

author: xda-developers.com
title: 4 reasons you shouldn't use an SSD for long-term backups
text:
Menu
Sign in now Close News & Deals Submenu News Deals Reviews Submenu Laptops CPUs Graphics cards SSDs Product Awards Best Guides Submenu Best Laptops Best Chromebooks Best CPUs Best graphics cards Tutorials Submenu Windows macOS Linux ChromeOS Threads Topics Submenu Acer Apple Dell HP Lenovo Microsoft Razer Sign in Newsletter Trending Copilot+ Snapdragon X Series Windows 11 2024 Update On this day Forums Close 4 reasons you shouldn't use an SSD for long-term backups SSD By Rich Edmonds Published 3 hours ago Thread Your changes have been saved
Email is sent
Email has already been sent
close Please verify your email address.
Send confirmation email close You’ve reached your account maximum for followed topics.
Manage Your List Follow Followed Follow with Notifications Follow Unfollow Share Facebook Flipboard Copy link Link copied to clipboard Sign in to your XDA account
When storing data for a long time, particularly backups, should you use a solid-state drive (SSD) or hard disk drive (HDD)? Although one should populate their NAS or external enclosure with a supported drive, I recommend against using SSDs for backing up all your data unless you'll frequently be writing new data to the drive(s). Here are some other reasons why HDDs may be the better option.
&#x2715 Remove Ads
Related SSD vs. HDD: Which should go in your PC? Running low on space in your PC? We're going to compare flashy vs. hard storage.
4 Finite offline data retention Close Did you know that if you power down your PC, take the SSD out, and store it somewhere for a year or two, there's a chance the data may not be retrievable? That's because an SSD works by using electricity to charge cells inside memory chips. The SSD continues to hold a small charge, even when powered off. If you don't connect the SSD to a power source and cycle it often, the drive will begin to discharge.
Depending on the temperature of the room where the SSD is stored, the time before the drive discharges and the data is lost. Writing a new backup to the drive will reset everything, but you'll encounter issues should you need to read the data from the SSD. A HDD, so long as it's securely stored in a safe location, will last much longer.
&#x2715 Remove Ads 3 Higher price per GB Close Solid-state drives have fallen in price over the years but are still considerably more pricey than hard drives. A 1TB SSD will set you back $40 for a 2.5-inch SATA drive, but an M.2 NVMe SSD with the same capacity can cost as much as $100 for faster transfer rates. A hard drive will set you back $100 for a whopping 10TB, beating the SSD on price and storage space, though it won't come anywhere near NVMe drives for performance.
Related Best hard drives for NAS If you're looking for new hard drives to increase the storage capacity of your NAS, you've come to the right place
2 Limited capacities Close &#x2715 Remove Ads You'll struggle to locate an SSD larger than 4TB. Even 8TB SSDs are incredibly rare with only a few models available and they cost a small fortune. For backing up data, it's simply not worth the additional cost, especially when you're restricted by the number of drive slots. An HDD can have a capacity of more than 20TB, so you won't need as many and can store much more data on each drive.
1 SSDs can fail without warning
Any drive can fail suddenly, but it's more likely to happen with an SSD. Although advances have been made to the technology over recent generations and you're less likely to encounter issues, a hard drive will still fail in a somewhat predictable way. You should have ample warning to move data off or replace the drive before things go wrong. Whereas an SSD could fail any minute now.
&#x2715 Remove Ads Consider how to store your data for the long term Network-attached storage devices are fantastic for storing data for longer periods. The same goes for backup drives, especially if you don't plan on changing data on these drives often. If you plan to use the drive frequently, an SSD will work well, but an HDD makes more sense if you wish to leave data on a drive for longer than a year.
Storage SSD backup Your changes have been saved

author: Khennia Reyes
title: Médicos recomiendan uso de cubrebocas ante condición Santa Ana
text: Médicos recomiendan uso de cubrebocas ante condición Santa Ana También es importante que los niños y adultos se vacunen contra la influenza y Covid-19. TIJUANA, BC.- En esta temporada de vientos de Santa Ana se recomienda el uso de cubrebocas para proteger las vías respiratorias de la contaminación y aprovechar las jornadas de vacunación contra el Covid-19 e influenza. El urgenciólogo Rodolfo Valtierra Picos, director de Servicios Médicos Industriales comentó que en estos días ventosos la salud de las personas que sufren sinusitis, rinitis u otro tipo de alergias pudiera empeorar ante la falta de cuidados, quienes deberán limitar salir a las calles. Te puede interesar: [Pronostican condición Santa Ana para Tijuana](https://www.elimparcial.com/tij/tijuana/2024/10/15/condicion-santa-ana-podria-llegar-la-proxima-semana/) Asimismo, aconsejó a la población en general acudir a consulta médica en caso de presentar tos, ojos rojos o escurrimiento nasal, con el propósito de recibir un tratamiento oportuno. Vacunación contra influenza y Covid-19 En cuanto a las vacunas, el especialista dijo que es importante que[ los niños y adultos se inmunicen contra la influenza y Covid-19,](https://www.elimparcial.com/mexico/2024/11/03/estas-son-las-tres-vacunas-que-debes-aplicarte-durante-la-temporada-de-frio-en-mexico/) pues en caso de contagiarse de ellas los síntomas serán menos severos. Te puede interesar: [Por qué algunas personas solo sufren de Covid, gripe y resfriados leves](https://www.elimparcial.com/locurioso/2024/11/07/por-que-algunas-personas-solo-sufren-de-covid-gripe-y-resfriados-leves/) El también director de la Clínica Primero Salud indicó que cada año es necesario vacunarse, puesto que dichos padecimientos son comunes en la época de frío. El Covid-19 no desapareció, simplemente mutó, es un virus que se transformó como el de influenza, es un virus que va venir de manera estacional año con año, la gran ventaja es que el Covid-19 es un virus donde sí hay alto riesgo de contagio, pero la letalidad es baja, lo mismo con la influenza”, explicó. Te puede interesar: [Diferencias entre resfriado, alergia y gripe: ¿Cuál es el más frecuente?](https://www.elimparcial.com/locurioso/2024/11/04/diferencias-entre-resfriado-alergia-y-gripe-cual-es-el-mas-frecuente/) De acuerdo a la Secretaría de Salud de Baja California, el módulo de vacunación contra el Covid-19 e influenza se ubica en la Jurisdicción de Salud Número 2 de 8:00 a 14:00 horas. La dependencia se encuentra cerca del Panteón Monte de los Olivos. Sigue nuestro canal de WhatsApp Recibe las noticias más importantes del día. Da click [aquí](https://www.elimparcial.com/boletin-whatsapp/)

author: 青网新闻郭森
title: 2024年我国造林种草767万公顷_新闻频道_中国青年网
text:
本报北京3月12日电 （记者李晓晴）今年3月12日是我国第四十七个植树节，记者从国家林草局获悉：《2024年中国国土绿化状况公报》显示，全国完成营造林444.6万公顷，种草改良322.4万公顷，治理沙化石漠化土地278.3万公顷，森林覆盖率超25%，森林蓄积量超200亿立方米。全年林草产业总产值达到10.17万亿元，同比增长9.6%，森林食物产量超2亿吨，成为继粮食、蔬菜之后的第三大重要农产品。
生态富民产业提质增效。全国经济林种植面积4666.7万公顷、年产值超2万亿元，林下经济利用林地面积4000万公顷、年产值约1万亿元。
“三北”工程攻坚战迈出坚实步伐。聚焦打好三大标志性战役，强化联防联治。全年安排中央资金320亿元，完成治理面积超380万公顷。
城乡绿化美化水平持续提升。开工建设口袋公园6200余个，建设城市绿道7300余公里。推进农村人居环境整治提升，大力实施农村“四旁”绿化。
山水林田湖草沙系统治理项目取得新进展。组织实施176个“双重”工程项目、10个国土绿化示范项目，持续推进“十四五”27个“山水工程”项目、49个历史遗留废弃矿山生态修复示范工程项目。新增水土流失治理面积6.4万平方公里。森林可持续经营实施面积扩大到66.7万公顷以上。全国林草碳汇试点市（县）和国有林场碳汇试点实施面积达6.8万公顷。

author: Redacción HuffPost
title: EEUU retira personal de Oriente Medio por la tensión con Irán, pese a que se confirma otra ronda de contactos
text:
EEUU retira personal de Oriente Medio por la tensión con Irán, pese a que se confirma otra ronda de contactos
Omán acogerá el domingo la sexta ronda de contactos entre sobre el programa nuclear de Teherán, pero Washington reacciona a la amenaza de ataques a sus bases por parte del régimen de los ayatolás.
El Gobierno estadounidense confirmó esta noche que retirará personal hasta dejar solo un destacamento indispensable en su embajada en la capital de Irak, Bagdad, ante el incremento de la tensión y los cruces de amenazas entre Estados Unidos e Irán por sus desavenencias en las negociaciones nucleares.
"El presidente Trump se compromete a mantener la seguridad de los estadounidenses, tanto dentro como fuera del país. En consonancia con este compromiso, evaluamos constantemente la situación del personal en todas nuestras embajadas. Con base en nuestro último análisis, decidimos reducir la presencia de nuestra Misión en Irak", explicó el Departamento de Estado en un comunicado remitido a EFE.
Funcionarios citados por medios estadounidenses han indicado también que el Departamento de Estado ha autorizado al personal no esencial en sus embajadas en las cercanas Manama (Baréin) y Kuwait a abandonar sus destinos si así lo desean, lo que da una idea del incremento de la tensión con Teherán.
La decisión de Washington llega después de que el ministro de Defensa iraní, Aziz Nasirzadeh, afirmara este mismo miércoles que atacará “todas” la bases de Estados Unidos en Oriente Medio en caso de que fracasen las negociaciones nucleares y el país persa sea atacado, tal y como ha amenazado con hacer el presidente Donald Trump.
Una ronda ilusionante y compleja
Irán y Estados Unidos mantienen unas negociaciones para alcanzar un acuerdo acerca del programa nuclear iraní que comenzaron el 12 de abril y cuya sexta ronda está prevista para esta semana, aunque parece haber desavenencias incluso sobre la fecha exacta de este próximo encuentro.
Estas conversaciones se están produciendo en medio de importantes desacuerdos sobre la capacidad de los ayatolás para enriquecer uranio, ya que Washington insiste en que Teherán no solo no debe poder fabricar bombas nucleares, sino quedar desprovisto también de la capacidad para procesar combustible atómico.
Trump ha insistido en sus amenazas militares contra el país persa en caso de no llegar a un acuerdo, mientras que Israel ha llamado a atacar las instalaciones nucleares iraníes para evitar que obtenga armas atómicas. Y el Consejo Supremo de Seguridad Nacional de Irán amenazó el lunes con atacar instalaciones nucleares “escondidas” de Israel en caso de ser atacado.
Sin embargo, las autoridades de Omán han confirmado este jueves que la nueva ronda de contactos entre las dos partes para abordar un posible acuerdo. "Me satisface confirmar que la sexta ronda de conversaciones entre Irán y Estados Unidos tendrá lugar en Mascate este domingo, 15 (de junio)", ha afirmado el ministro de Exteriores omaní, Badr al Busaidi, a través de su cuenta en la red social X.
Por su parte, el portavoz del Ministerio de Exteriores iraní, Esmaeil Baqaei, confirmó el lunes que Teherán presentará "pronto" una contrapropuesta a Estados Unidos, tras rechazar las exigencias de Washington para que Irán ponga fin a los trabajos de enriquecimiento de uranio.
Los contactos entre las partes, que han mantenido ya cinco encuentros durante las últimas semanas, son los primeros de este tipo desde la retirada de Washington en 2018 del histórico acuerdo nuclear firmado tres años antes, una medida adoptada durante el primer mandato de Trump (2017-2021), que ahora ha apostado por relanzar las conversaciones para intentar forjar un nuevo acuerdo con Teherán.
topics: War, Conflict and Unrest->international military intervention
